Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2012 09:46AM BilateralBeauties wrote: Remember, early detection saves lives. Maybe a breast MRI would be good too if they are having trouble distinguishing. Ask about it or you might be making a third trip.
Posts.Title: I know what I need to do............... cheriann worried50

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2013 07:07AM BilateralBeauties wrote: I used Miaderm, started a week before rads. When blistered switched to aquaphor. I had a couple of days of disrupted treatment. It seems more common than not. I was bilateral and busty so had a tough time. No limitations now 1 year later. Keep up stretching especially after rads ends. Keep pecs stretched. Good luck.
Posts.Title: A rad onc weighs in on radiation "burns" Spinnerpom 53nancy

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2013 01:14PM BilateralBeauties wrote: Same here. I had a large (4cm) ovarian cyst detected before chemo started. After treatment was done, I started vomiting all the time, especially at night. After 10 months of proving I had the same liver stuff as you and noting gallstones, it was determined the gallbladder had to come out. Tamoxifen greatly riled my gallbladder and pain was atypical - left side, not right, so we looked for everything before digging deeper on gallbladder. So if you start with weird abdominal pains or shoulder pain, have them look at gallbladder right away. The other stuff is completely normal. Exhale and have some fun.
Posts.Title: Ovary cyst B123 B123

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2013 11:08AM BilateralBeauties wrote: B123, there isn't a doctor in the world that will act on an asymptomatic gallbladder. We've always lived with our natural selves and that doesn't change after cancer. Try to find a support group where you can air your concerns and carry on. My liver stuff is hemangiomas - we are all born with them. My gallbladder did come out, because I was up all night vomiting two days a week for 10 months. We deal with stuff when we have to, but not for reassurance. Reassurance comes from our relationships and interactions with others. We were diagnosed the same month. I'm just now starting to find some calm. Find some things to distract you from your catastrophic thinking. I trust my doctors very much and know they would not harm me. Try to feel some reassurance from your medical team.
Posts.Title: Ovary cyst B123 B123

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2013 03:43PM BilateralBeauties wrote: I'm not familiar with Zoladex or its SEs. I'm serious about trying something new that you haven't tried before. I would recommend acupuncture. I don't know if you've spent any time learning about qi or your chakras? The abdomen is the center of our emotional selves. You need to get all that energy that is stuck there moving. Trust what your doctors say and find another something to focus on. I'm also a believer in chiropractic. Find a chiropractor that does acupuncture. It can really be nothing. We just don't know what to do with all the anguish. It's prudent to keep investigating, but when it all still looks like nothing, try something new. My cancer resource center offers some free services - healing touch, massage, etc. My saving grace was a health coach that spent a ton of time with me and I could vent all my stuff and then we focused on food - good, healthy food and an intro to yoga. She gave me enough confidence that I went to a yoga class in the community. Yoga Nidra is a yoga nap, more or less. Look for a local session. There is so much modern medicine can't help us with, we have to seek other opportunities to find relief in things we don't really understand, but are worth a shot... If you can manage the anxiety, the pain can become more manageable. I had a lot of time up all night vomiting and writhing in pain to try stuff. I tried the meditation CD from this person and did chanting. http://www.redtwigyoga.com/products.html. It seemed to help. It was a way to focus on something other than the pain. It also will help clear your Chakras. Breathe is also good. My health coach introduced me to these things. (((Hugs)))
Posts.Title: Ovary cyst B123 B123

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2013 04:59PM BilateralBeauties wrote: I hired a health coach as part of my treatment and it was helpful to get my head around all the contradicting information. Nutrition is a science full of contradictions and every opinion is different. There are a few universals, eat plant-based foods and especially greens, onions and mushrooms. I have adopted what I call a directionally vegan diet. I feel better. I have gained weight, but for the first time in five years, my glucose levels have returned to normal. It might be worth looking into the Alkaline vs Acidic diet. Cancer grows easier in an acidic state. Red meat, sugars are highly acidic. My diet changes are for my mental health. Something I can control. I was growing cancers two at a time with my old diet so why not change it up.
Posts.Title: Do any of you restrict certain foods? brandall SchnauzerMom

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2013 02:28PM BilateralBeauties wrote: I haven't heard that BRCA has any impact on Oncotype scores. I had two tumors, both very small and got one of the highest Oncotype of seen for ER/PR+. I was 42. For a 7mm tumor, I got chemo. They will want to pay close attention to your ovaries, but will rely on the Oncotype. Another friend had a 3 cm tumor, but no chemo as very low Oncotype. It is all an odds game, but for a low Oncotype, the risks of chemo are worse than the risk of reoccurance. Even with chemo, my risk remains higher than many low Oncos. I think the test has really helped prevent over treatment. They likely will start you on Tamoxifen or similar if you haven't already. Good luck.

I had lumpectomies and radiation, but skin is quite sensitive. I can't stand certain fabrics whether seams or not. I'm also super busty, but Nordstrom's product is the best for me.

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2012 03:10PM BilateralBeauties wrote: Good luck. Sending positive thoughts your way.
Posts.Title: First result paminindy BilateralBeauties

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2012 01:29PM BilateralBeauties wrote: Oncotype score helps here too. My score was 42, which equated to a 35% chance of reoccurance. Even though tumor was only 7mm, I had chemo. It is an odds game. So now chemo, radiation and tamoxifen, my chance is 10% reoccurance. One has to look at all the data and make a decision. If you are triple negative. Always chemo. Her2+ always chemo (I think). ER+/PR+ Her2- with low oncotype score, small tumor, no chemo. That's the rules of thumb I'm aware of. Chemo is doable. We'll get you through.
Posts.Title: Is Chemotherapy necessary? cindyski itsjustme10

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2013 07:02AM BilateralBeauties wrote: This stage is the worst. I went from one tumor in left breast to bilateral breast cancer, two different kinds in a week. The rate that information comes at you in the early days is hard to manage. Getting through surgery will give you a richer picture. Until the nodes are out, nothing is definate. I'm not sure of your hormone status, but long-term survival is real. I have a friend that was triple negative that just celebrated 16 years of survival. I have met many ER+/PR+ long term survivors as well. Getting through surgery gives a better picture. Hang in there. During this crazy period I was trying acupuncture, massage and anything to help calm the stress. Hugs. BB

Bilateral radiation was the hardest part of treatment, neuropathy is the hardest part of survival. On Tamoxifen and fighting weight gain. MX vs lumpies is personal. One can always take more off, but when its gone its gone. So since life expectancy is the SAME for lumpectomy, I kept mine at 43. I refer to it as "rack worth saving." My hubby and I are still enjoying the playground.

I would do them both together. Having had cancer, a short service on the other side (less than a year) shouldn't be a big deal. Good luck.
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2013 05:12PM BilateralBeauties wrote: Tortoise, to help give you peace of mind, perhaps you can tell your mother your wishes and leave here with a note or message to my children that could be shared with all if you are not able to be as active in parenting. Children grow so fast. Write it for a six year old and revisit it every two years and provide updates. The overwhelm that comes with this disease is awful. I don't know what to say about DH, but I would caution you on backing him into a corner about things after death. That's a horrible conversation. If he loses his wife, he will need his mom. Maybe re-engage with a list of things you agree on rather than fight about what you don't. Build from a positive. First thing to agree on - live each day, honor each other. I had a very positive diagnosis and remember at one point having a huge fight with my hubby and saying to him "I don't trust you to consider my best interests." The flip side is they are overwhelmed too. Hugs and love. If you can't speak words, try holding hands.

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2013 06:11AM BilateralBeauties wrote: It is common to be called back after a first mammogram as the radiologists can't compare it against any other tests. Going back and forth between mammography and ultrasound is common. After my first mammogram I was put on a 6-month recheck, but what they initially watched wasn't anything. A recheck is just that - a thorough baseline for you. Hopefully they will be comfortable with what they see and not do biopsies. Good Luck.
Posts.Title: Call back after first Mammo -asymmetry in both breasts stnkyferit stnkyferit

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2013 04:21PM BilateralBeauties wrote: I found out over the phone - twice - within a week. Definately have someone with you at your first appt. My hubby went sometimes and a girlfriend the other. He couldn't always take it. In my case, it's the Breast Center that calls. So the conversation went something like this. Hi how's your biopsy site. Fine. Well you have cancer, who is your surgeon? Holy shit, I don't have a surgeon. I'll call you back in 10 minutes with an appt. And that was how I got a surgeon. Hubby had to get on a plane and fly home. Meeting with surgeon will lead to conversation about lumpectomy vs masectomy and husbands need to hear that stuff first hand. Good luck.

Ask your doctor to get a baseline mammogram now. Good luck.

Posts.Title: When can you stop seeing an oncologist? terrij152 Artista928

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2013 07:31PM BilateralBeauties wrote: I had a a healthy discussion with RO about this as I was bilateral. I wanted to do the 5-day therapy. One of the things that happens at radiation is we are already disease fatigued. We want it over. ROs are in a tough spot to get us through the "gold standard" protocol with all the stuff running through our heads. We can all choose what we want to do, but if you understand the science they abide by - when we don't do the full protocol, women pay with their lives. You don't say how old you are. I consuluted a couple of ROs and neither would have provided they 5-day brachy even though I was stage 1 and 7mm and 11mm tumors. The RO I went with said he wouldn't recommend Bracy if I were 65 as the 5 year survival is not as good as the gold standard. They know the science. They are passionate about the protocol, because they know the numbers. They know the stats on how things work out in the end. As far as how many days, all I can say is cancer is sneaky and radiation is cumulative. Their math is based on survival stats of women like us. They are truly about our survival. I truly believe we are more about getting our lives back ASAP when we get to radiation and they have a tough job getting through to us. I know that was the case with me. And when it registered, I cried. It was the last thing in the world I wanted. And it sucked. But whatever the future holds, I swung with the biggest bat the smartest doctors on the planet offered. In the end, it's the gift of life to myself. We should also remember, that there is extensive history with radiation that supercedes any of our chemo protocols. It hasn't changed much in a long time. The reason it hasn't changes is nothing has proven to be better. Going less will give you some defense, but not the "gold standard" of defense.
Posts.Title: I DO NOT want 28 days of radiation and no boosts! Katski foxford

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2013 05:15PM BilateralBeauties wrote: I finished chemo in Dec. 2011. I had neurapathy throughout treatment. hands, feet, legs face. I did great from April to November. Starting in the winter months, my neuropathy has flaired in all the areas I previously had it. It doesn't wake me up at night, but it is very distracting and probably a 3 on the pain scale. I'm hoping it disappears again with the warm weather. Let me know if any of you have noticed seasonal differences.

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2012 10:10AM BilateralBeauties wrote: I had oncotype done on both of my tumors. The larger (11 mm), lower grade was 14 and would have had no chemo. The smaller (7 mm) was grade three and Oncotype 42. That required chemo even though so small. Getting your score is an excellent guidepost and your MO can help you understand. It's great progress to not overtreat with chemo.

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2013 09:30PM BilateralBeauties wrote: It is never bad to have the cancer out. We can always take more off. My surgery moved really fast, which was important to me. I couldn't stand another day with my tumors. Others take more time. It is personal preference in many cases. I actually did see the oncologist before surgery. My surgeon made me. I was actually resistant and the oncologist agreed to see me the next day. My surgeon expedited it as I did not want to wait. Even with lumpectomies, people can end up with multiple surgeries. It is not ideal, but it happens. I have met a women who had her lumpectomy redone 4 times to get clean margins.

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2012 04:42AM BilateralBeauties wrote: I had bilateral rads that ended in February. No concerns at this point. I lost significant skin during the last weeks of treatment. Full-body inflamation at the end. Getting back to normal now. Breast tissue is closer to normal feeling. Pain has subsided. My RO was pretty aggressive that those that don't follow 33 rads protocol pay with their lives. I was asking about the 5 day rads and again length of life concerns from his standpoint. We all have to decide for ourselves on the risk/benefit piece.

Posts.Title: Scared to Death.. DeJaVuAgain Kelloggs

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2013 08:02PM BilateralBeauties wrote: Welcome to the odds game. I was 43 at diagnosis, but my Oncotype was 42, so I was shoved down the tube of lumpectomy, chemo, rads. Even with all that treatment, my reoccurance numbers is about 15%. My tumors were exceptionally small. Mr. 42 was 7mm. Having had chemo, one of my biggest complaints is life long neuropathy. It is bad in the winter. For 4 percentage points, I think I would skip chemo. That said, my other mantra is cancer is sneaky and we have to swing with the big bat. The real key is making the decision and never looking back. Because my number is still so high, I have eliminated meat and as much animal estrogen from my diet as I can and am trying to improve my odds with my lifestyle. Chemo is doable. I didn't miss work except treatment day. Had CT x4. Jump on tamoxifen and be loyal even if it isn't perfect. Also, did they Oncotype all of your tumors? Do they know for sure if they were all the same? If there's any doubt there, I'd say bring the chemo baby. Hugs and good luck.
Posts.Title: In your 40's with low Oncotype score, what was your decision? gracebead p22nut5

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2012 01:21PM BilateralBeauties wrote: The Oncotype score will give you a geneitic profile on how aggressive your cancer is. At this time, scores under 20 are mostly no chemo. Scores 20-30, lots of discussion. Anything over 30, throw chemo at it. I also thought if nodes were involved chemo was automatic. It means your cancer has moved from breast to blood tissue. I would be looking for a second opionion with this. They will not start chemo or hormone therapy pills until you have healed. My lumpectomies were Sept. 7 and I started chemo Oct. 13. This was followed by radiation and then hormone therapy. If no chemo, hormone therapy often starts sooner. There's a big difference between 9% and 25% (1 in 10 women with reoccurance or 1 in 4 women with reoccurance). This would be enough for me to get chemo. You don't state your age. I was 43 at diagnosis. With radiation and hormone therapy, by Oncotype reoccurence score had a 33% reoccurance rate. Chemo dropped it to 10-15 percent. I believe in swinging with the big bat and then live with gusto. We can't second guess ourselves. Some positives in your diagnosis is the ER/PR + and Her2-. This is the most treatable type and there are many options. Find out more about yours.
Posts.Title: saw oncologist today.....more confused than ever, help! jabal Cherilynn64

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2013 09:56PM BilateralBeauties wrote: When tumors have multiple receptor status, Oncs. look to treat most aggressive kind as their priority.
Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed now MRI finds a 2nd Lump jfelice Camillia

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2012 02:14PM BilateralBeauties wrote: The key is to make your decision and not look back. At age 43 I wanted to swing with the biggest bat possible to try to see my son to adulthood. If you have children and they are all adults, the decision may be somewhat easier. Cancer is a sneaky thing. Over treatment is real. Recommened treatment regimen is saving lives. Oncotype of 26 is the high end of score range being evaluated for improved response from chemo. Make the decision. Live life. No regrets.
Posts.Title: Has anyone decided not to do chemo? Lully adagio

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2013 06:30AM BilateralBeauties wrote: Another option is to push for a recheck in 3 months. There are many watchful waiters that have quarterly visits. Our breasts change all the time. 80% of what radiologists biopsy is benign. They were not concerned enough to biopsy at this time. You could also ask for a better clarification of why no biopsy now? Ask they to explain how it does not look like cancer. If it looked like cancer, they would have biopsied.
Posts.Title: Will I regret 'waiting and seeing'? hbranden9 hbranden9

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2013 11:28AM BilateralBeauties wrote: I was 43 at time of treatment. My ROs philosophy was women who get mammosite pay with their lives. At my age he would not consider it. Another RO told me if they do it they generally place at time of lumpectomy, but he also would not do for a young woman. I have posted about this before, so hopefully you can find some of these threads. External Beam is still the gold standard. I know a woman who had it at 84 and she is still going at 91. Good luck.
